Thanks for the idea; looks like System.setOut() will do just what I want.

=
But your answer raises another question; why do I have to 'reset' the Print=
stream for each test; I thought all the tests were independent and that the=
re wouldn't be leftover state from prior test to confund a later test.

Cou=
ld this be related to a problem I had with the test suite with several simi=
lar test that wrote to a file: the output file of th 2nd tests contained th=
e output of the 1st and 2nd test, the ouput of the 3rd contained the output=
 of the 1st, 2nd, and 3rd tests.  I ended up having to write separate class=
es to get all the tests done.

Thanks again,

Cheers,

jim


--- In junit@y=
ahoogroups.com, "Bob Runstein" <rrunstein@...> wrote:
>
> 
> 
> --- In juni=
t@yahoogroups.com, "cant_jim" <jimcant@> wrote:
> >
> > How can I capture t=
he standard output of test? I need to check that
> the messages from the cl=
ass I'm testing are correct. For example if my
> class class calls a parser=
 that print "invalid input at line xx" when it
> fails, I want to be able g=
o catch that output and compare it to the
> expected value. If it could be =
directed to a file on a per-test basis, I
> could do a diff to check it.
> =
>
> > Any suggestions would be appreciated.
> >
> > Thanks,
> >
> > Jim Can=
t
> >
> 
> You can override the default behavior of System.out.println() us=
ing
> System.setOut(PrintStream).  Subclass PrintStream and override the pr=
int
> methods to log to a file that you can specify.  Even better, add a
> =
StringBuilder member with setter and getter to the PrintStream and
> overri=
de the print methods to append to that.  Your test can do
> assertEquals on=
 your expected value and the toString value of the
> StringBuilder.  Don't =
forget to reset the PrintStream before each test.
>
